questions.explanation: Cellular respiration is a metabolic process that provides energy. While it is regulated by homeostatic mechanisms, it is not a homeostatic mechanism itself.

questions.question: In man, diabetes mellitus is a disease of the pancreas while diabetes insipidus is a disease of the
questions.explanation: Diabetes mellitus is caused by a problem with insulin production in the pancreas. Diabetes insipidus is caused by a deficiency of ADH from the pituitary gland, which affects kidney function.

questions.question: The process of removing the amino group from amino acids is called
questions.explanation: Deamination is the metabolic process that removes an amino group from an amino acid, with the amino group converted to urea and the carbon skeleton used for energy or storage.

questions.question: The fig represents an experiment with two types of soil. The experiment demonstrates
questions.explanation: Capillarity is the tendency of water to rise in narrow spaces against gravity. Key takeaway: This property is crucial for water movement from deeper soil layers to plant roots.

questions.question: Which of these is not a type of soil?
questions.explanation: Granite is an igneous rock that may weather to form soil components. Important: While rocks break down into soil particles, granite itself remains a rock type, not a soil classification.

questions.question: The farmer cannot check soil erosion effectively by
questions.explanation: Vegetation removal increases erosion by exposing soil to wind and water. Therefore, soil conservation requires maintaining ground cover rather than removing it.

questions.question: If three 30 cm lengths of glass tubing are tightly packed with clay, sand and loamy soils respectively and then stood in a beaker of water for one week, the level of water will be
options: lowest in the tube with clay
the same in all the tubes
lowest in the tube with loamy soil
lowest in the tube with sandy soil
questions.explanation: Sandy soil has large pore spaces and poor capillary action. Remember: Sand drains quickly but retains minimal water compared to clay soils.

questions.question: Leguminous plants, e.g Mucuna, are usually planted in cultivated farmlands because they
options: enrich the soil with organic nitrogen
protect the soil from being overheated
questions.explanation: Legumes host Rhizobium bacteria that fix atmospheric N2 into plant-usable forms. Note: This natural fertilization reduces dependence on chemical nitrogen fertilizers.

questions.question: A few grams of dried soil were first heated until red hot and then further heated until no more smoke was released. This experiment was to determine the
questions.explanation: Humus (organic matter) contains carbon that produces smoke when burned. Key takeaway: First heating removes water; second heating burns organic matter.

questions.question: In which of the following plants is swollen shoot disease common?
questions.explanation: Swollen shoot disease is a viral infection specific to cocoa plants. Important: This disease has devastated cocoa production in West Africa.

questions.question: Soil is said to be fertile if
options: it can supply usable nutrients to plant
The oxygen content is very high
artificial manure is added to it
questions.explanation: Fertility depends on nutrient availability, not color. Therefore, even dark soils can be infertile if nutrients are locked up and unavailable to plants.

questions.question: Treatment of a poor soil with lime supplies
questions.explanation: Lime contains calcium compounds like CaCO3. Remember: Lime also reduces soil acidity and improves soil structure through flocculation.

questions.question: If a farmer left his land uncultivated for five years before returning to it.
questions.explanation: Bush fallowing allows soil recovery through natural vegetation growth. Note: This traditional method helps restore soil nutrients and structure.

questions.question: A 28g soil sample was heated to a constant weight of 24g. When further heated to red hot and cooled, it weighed 18g. What is the percentage of humus in the soil?
questions.explanation: %humus = (24-18)/28 × 100% = 6/28 × 100% = 21.43%. Key takeaway: Weight difference after red-hot heating represents organic matter content.

questions.question: Erosion can be reduced along a slope by
questions.explanation: Contour ridging (across slope) slows water runoff. Important: Ridging along the slope actually accelerates erosion by creating channels for water.

questions.question: If a handful of soil is shaken with water and left to settle, the soil particles will settle from light to heavy particles as follows:
questions.explanation: Sedimentation separates particles by size. Remember: Clay particles (<0.002mm) are smallest, while sand (0.02-2.0mm) and gravel (>2.0mm) are larger.

questions.question: Leaching is
options: washing away of humus from the soil surface
reduction of soil aeration by pressure
soil erosion by means other than rainfall
washing out of chalk and limestone from upper layers of soil by heavy rains
questions.explanation: Leaching is vertical movement of soluble nutrients downward. Therefore, this process causes nutrient depletion and soil acidity in tropical regions.

questions.question: The process of soil erosion is usually from
questions.explanation: Sheet erosion → Rill erosion → Gully erosion. Note: This progression shows how minor surface removal can develop into deep, permanent gullies.

questions.question: Soil erosion CANNOT be controlled by
questions.explanation: Burning removes protective vegetation cover. Key takeaway: Fire exposes soil to both water and wind erosion agents.

questions.question: Water retention is highest in soils which are rich in
options: sand, poor in humus and devoid of clay
clay and sand, but poor in humus
clay and humus, but poor in sand
clay, poor in humus and devoid of sand
questions.explanation: Clay has fine particles that hold water tightly. Humus acts like a sponge. Therefore, the combination provides maximum water retention.

questions.question: The origin of mineral particles in the soil is
questions.explanation: Rocks break down through weathering processes. Remember: Physical, chemical, and biological weathering all contribute to soil formation.

questions.question: The initial volume of water poured into a bag of dry soil was 50ml and the amount that drained through was 35ml. The percentage water content of the fully soaked soil is therefore
questions.explanation: % water = (50 - 35)/50 × 100% = 30%. Key takeaway: Water content indicates soil's water-holding capacity.

questions.question: The swollen shoot disease of cocoa tree is caused by a
questions.explanation: Viral infection causes characteristic swelling of shoots. Important: Viral diseases are difficult to treat and often require infected plant removal.

questions.question: A large percentage of tropical soils tend to be acidic because they
options: lose a high proportion of their organic matter to running water
lose lime and potash from the top soil through rain action
questions.explanation: Leaching removes basic cations (Ca2+, K+, Mg2+). Therefore, hydrogen ions dominate, creating acidity.

questions.question: The following are methods of soil conservation EXCEPT
questions.explanation: Mixed grazing involves animal management, not direct soil protection. Note: Overgrazing can actually cause erosion.

questions.question: Samples of different soil types are packed in glass tubes whose lower ends are plugged with cotton wool. If these tubes are suspended in a trough of water, water will rise highest after a few hours in
questions.explanation: Clay has smallest pores, creating strongest capillary forces. Remember: This capillary rise is crucial for water movement to plant roots in fine-textured soils.

questions.question: The process by which lime is added to clay soils is known as
questions.explanation: Flocculation refers to aggregation of fine clay particles. Key takeaway: Lime causes clay particles to clump together, improving soil structure.

questions.question: The mineral nutrient that is most bound to the soil is
questions.explanation: Iron forms insoluble oxides like Fe2O3. Therefore, iron availability is often limited despite high total content in soil.

questions.question: The mineral nutrient that easily gets leached out of the soil is
questions.explanation: Calcium ions (Ca2+) are highly soluble and mobile. Note: This is why liming is frequently needed in high-rainfall areas.

questions.question: Most commercial fertilizers are rich in salts of
questions.explanation: NPK fertilizers contain nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). Remember: These are the three primary macronutrients plants need in largest quantities.

questions.question: 5g of oven dried soil was heated in a furnace for 24 hours, after cooling, it weighed 4.8g what is the amount of humus in the soil?
questions.explanation: % humus = (5.0 - 4.8)/5 × 100% = 4.0%. Key takeaway: Organic matter content is a key indicator of soil fertility.

questions.question: Most irrigated lands often become unproductive in later years because of
questions.explanation: Continuous cropping depletes nutrients without adequate replacement. Therefore, sustainable agriculture requires nutrient management and crop rotation.

questions.question: Farmers practice crop rotation because it
options: allows two crops to be planted at the same time
is an alternative to shifting cultivation
questions.explanation: Different crops have different nutrient demands. Note: Including legumes in rotation adds nitrogen, reducing fertilizer needs.

questions.question: An acidic soil can be improved upon by
questions.explanation: Flocculation (liming) neutralizes acidity. Remember: Lime raises pH, makes nutrients more available, and improves soil structure.

questions.question: Fertilizers are lost from the soil through
options: Leaching, underground seepages and run off
sheet erosion, gully erosion and wind erosion
questions.explanation: Soluble nutrients move with water. Key takeaway: This is why split applications of fertilizer are more efficient than single large doses.

questions.question: Soil with the finest particles is called
questions.explanation: Clay particles are <0.002 mm in diameter. Important: This fine texture gives clay its high surface area and reactivity.

questions.question: Soil fertility can be conserved and renewed by
options: bush burning to remove unwanted debris
questions.explanation: Cover crops protect soil; rotation balances nutrient use. Therefore, these practices maintain long-term productivity.

questions.question: The water-retention capacity of a soil indicates its
questions.explanation: Capillarity determines how well soil holds water against gravity. Remember: High capillarity means better water availability between rainfall events.

questions.question: In a soil sample, the relative amounts of the different soil particles can best be determined by the process of
questions.explanation: Sedimentation separates particles by size in water. Note: Larger particles settle faster, creating distinct layers.

questions.question: Soil micro-organisms are beneficial because of their involvement in
questions.explanation: Microbes decompose organic matter, releasing nutrients. Key takeaway: This nutrient cycling is essential for sustainable soil fertility.

questions.question: A soil consisting of alumina and iron (III) oxide is known as
questions.explanation: Laterite contains Al2O3 and Fe2O3. Important: This soil forms in tropical climates with heavy leaching and is often infertile.

questions.question: The soil becomes toxic to plants when the concentration of its essential elements is in the range labelled IV. This shows that
questions.explanation: Nutrient toxicity occurs at high concentrations. Therefore, proper fertilizer application requires understanding optimal ranges.

questions.question: The range at which soil essential element concentration is recorded for optimal plant growth is marked II. This demonstrates
options: deficiency and toxicity both limit growth
questions.explanation: Optimal growth occurs within specific nutrient ranges. Remember: Both deficiency and excess can reduce crop yields.

questions.question: The addition of lime to clay soil serve to
questions.explanation: Lime improves drainage by aggregating clay particles. Key takeaway: Better drainage reduces water-logging and improves root aeration.

questions.question: The excessive use of agro-chemicals could lead to the pollution of
questions.explanation: Chemicals can leach into groundwater or run off into surface water. Important: This pollution affects drinking water and aquatic ecosystems.

questions.question: The stunted growth of a leguminous plant suffering from nitrogen deficiency may be corrected by inoculating the soil with
questions.explanation: Rhizobium bacteria form symbiotic relationships with legumes. Note: Inoculation introduces effective nitrogen-fixing bacteria to the soil.

questions.question: Soil fertility can best be conserved and renewed by the activities of
questions.explanation: Microbial decomposition releases nutrients from organic matter. Therefore, healthy soil microbiology is essential for nutrient cycling.

questions.question: The soil type that will be most difficult to plough in a wet season is one that is
questions.explanation: Clay becomes sticky and plastic when wet. Remember: This makes tillage difficult and can lead to soil compaction.

questions.question: A farm practice that results in the loss of soil fertility is
questions.explanation: Continuous cropping extracts nutrients without replacement. Key takeaway: Monoculture particularly accelerates nutrient depletion.

questions.question: Which of the following is used to test for the presence of lime in a soil sample?
questions.explanation: HCl reacts with CaCO3 to produce CO2 gas. Note: Effervescence indicates lime presence: CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + H2O + CO2.

questions.question: The importance of practicing crop rotation in agriculture is to
options: improve the nutritional value of crops
questions.explanation: Rotation balances nutrient demands and breaks pest cycles. Therefore, it's a key strategy for sustainable soil management.

questions.question: The soil type that contains nutrients which are not readily available for plants is
questions.explanation: Clay tightly binds nutrients to its surface. Important: While clay has high nutrient content, availability to plants can be limited.

questions.question: The increasing order of the particle size in the following soil types is
questions.explanation: Clay (<0.002mm) < Silt (0.002-0.02mm) < Sand (0.02-2.0mm) < Gravel (>2.0mm). Remember: This size classification determines soil texture.

questions.question: A crucible of 5gm weighed 10 gm after filling with fresh soil. It is then heated in an oven at 100°C for 1 hour. After cooling in a desiccator, the weight was 8 gm. The percentage of water in the soil is
questions.explanation: Water weight = 10-8 = 2gm; Soil weight = 10-5 = 5gm; % water = 2/5 × 100% = 40%. Key takeaway: Moisture content affects soil workability and plant water availability.

questions.question: In an experiment to determine the percentage of air in a soil sample, the following readings were recorded: Volume of soil added to water = 350cm³; Volume of water and soil after stirring = 800cm³. The percentage of air in the soil sample is
questions.explanation: Air volume = (500+350) - 800 = 50cm³; % air = 50/350 × 100% = 14.29%. Note: Soil air content affects root respiration and microbial activity.

questions.question: Mass of a crucible = 10g; Mass of a crucible and soil before heating = 29g; Mass of a crucible and soil after heating = 18g. From the information above, determine the percentage of water in the given soil sample?
questions.explanation: Water mass = 29-18 = 11g; Soil mass = 29-10 = 19g; % water = 11/19 × 100% = 57.89%. Therefore, none of the given options match the correct calculation.

questions.question: The loss of soil through erosion can be reduced by
questions.explanation: Crop rotation maintains ground cover throughout the year. Remember: Continuous vegetation cover is key to erosion control.

questions.question: In an experiment to determine the percentage of humus and water in a soil sample, weight of humus was 3.5g and weight of soil was 21.0g. The percentage of humus is
questions.explanation: % humus = 3.5/21.0 × 100% = 16.7%. Key takeaway: Humus improves soil structure, water retention, and nutrient availability.

questions.question: An indigenous method of renewing and maintaining soil fertility is by
questions.explanation: Traditional methods work with natural processes. Therefore, these approaches can be sustainable when properly managed.

questions.question: The soil with the highest water-retaining capacity is
questions.explanation: Clayey soil has fine particles and small pores. Important: While it retains water well, it may not make water readily available to plants.
